title: Character Encoding
desc: Explore ASCII, Unicode, UTF-8/16/32 and more

unicode.title: Unicode Character Set
unicode.intro: Unicode is a universal character encoding standard that aims to represent every character from every writing system in the world.
unicode.codepoint_desc: A code point is a number assigned to a character. Written as U+XXXX (e.g., U+0041 for 'A').
unicode.plane0: Plane 0 (BMP): U+0000 - U+FFFF - Basic Multilingual Plane, contains most common characters
unicode.plane1: Plane 1 (SMP): U+10000 - U+1FFFF - Supplementary Multilingual Plane, emoji, historic scripts
unicode.plane2: Plane 2 (SIP): U+20000 - U+2FFFF - CJK Extension B and later

utf8.title: UTF-8 Encoding
utf8.intro: UTF-8 is a variable-width encoding that uses 1-4 bytes per character. It's backward compatible with ASCII.
utf8.adv1: ASCII compatible - ASCII text is valid UTF-8
utf8.adv2: Self-synchronizing - easy to find character boundaries

utf16.title: UTF-16 and UTF-32
utf16.utf16_intro: UTF-16 uses 2 or 4 bytes per character. It uses surrogate pairs for characters outside the BMP.
utf16.surrogate_desc: Characters with code points > 0xFFFF are encoded as a pair of 16-bit code units:
utf16.utf32_intro: UTF-32 uses exactly 4 bytes per character, making it simple but space-inefficient.
utf16.be_desc: Big Endian (BE): Most significant byte first
utf16.le_desc: Little Endian (LE): Least significant byte first
utf16.bom_desc: The BOM (U+FEFF) at the start of a file indicates the byte order.

gbk.title: GBK and Chinese Encodings
gbk.gb2312_desc: The first Chinese character encoding standard, covering 6,763 simplified Chinese characters.
gbk.gbk_desc: An extension of GB2312, adding traditional Chinese characters and more symbols. Total ~21,886 characters.
gbk.gb18030_desc: The current Chinese national standard, fully compatible with Unicode. Variable length 1-4 bytes.
gbk.structure_desc: GBK uses 2 bytes per Chinese character. First byte: 0x81-0xFE, Second byte: 0x40-0xFE.

history.title: Character Encoding History
history.ascii_desc: 7-bit encoding for English, 128 characters including control codes.
history.chaos_desc: Different regions created incompatible encodings: ISO-8859 for Europe, GB2312/Big5 for Chinese, Shift-JIS for Japanese.
history.unicode_desc: Unicode was created to provide a single encoding for all languages. UTF-8 became the dominant web encoding.
history.today_desc: UTF-8 is used by over 98% of websites. It's the default encoding for HTML5, JSON, and most modern systems.
